text.p: The following are top headlines from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- British Columbia deficit could balloon: Balanced-budget goal delayed a year, 1996-97 shortfall may total $400 million.
- Relief workers forced to leave Zairian camps.
- Employees relocate to help ill parents: Mobile labour force, cutbacks in services mean Canadian companies face more requests for transfers.
- Partial cod recovery perplexes Canadian scientists: Stocks still scarce in deep waters but bountiful inshore.
- Model campaign propels Clinton toward second term.
- British phone giant BT to swallow MCI: Rivals 'won't see us for dust,' U.K phone chief boasts of US$21-billion deal.
- U.S. election crucial for tobacco: Republican victories would snuff offensive against cigarettes.
- Canada scrambles for direct-to-home satellite service: Modest version in works for year-end.
- Retail stocks - 'tis the reason to be jolly.
- Canadian Airlines sends an SOS: Company faces cash crunch and needs emergency wage cuts, route shifts and reductions in service fees to keep it flying.
- Barrick Gold also has links to family of Indonesia's Suharto.
- Extremes of rich and poor in U.S. election.
